quiz.title: Unit 7: Labor Markets (Quiz 25)
quiz.subtitle: 7.1 Derived Demand for Labor: Labor Demand from Product Demand (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Labor Demand, Derived Demand, Marginal Revenue Product, Factor Markets

questions.question: The demand for labor is described as a 'derived demand' because:
options: It is determined by government regulations
It depends on the demand for the products that labor produces
It is derived from workers' preferences
It comes from international labor markets
questions.explanation: Labor demand is derived from the demand for the final goods and services that workers help produce. Firms don't hire labor for its own sake, but for what it can produce.

questions.question: The marginal revenue product of labor (MRP) is calculated as:
options: Marginal product × Price of output
Total product ÷ Number of workers
Wage rate × Hours worked
Total revenue ÷ Total workers
questions.explanation: $MRP_L = MP_L \times P$ where $MP_L$ is the marginal product of labor and $P$ is the price of output. For imperfect competitors, $MRP_L = MP_L \times MR$.

questions.question: A profit-maximizing firm will hire workers up to the point where:
options: Wage = Average product
Wage = Marginal revenue product
Total revenue is maximized
Average cost is minimized
questions.explanation: Firms hire additional workers as long as the MRP (additional revenue from one more worker) exceeds or equals the wage (additional cost of one more worker).

questions.question: If the marginal revenue product of labor exceeds the wage rate, a firm should:
options: Hire more workers
Hire fewer workers
Keep the same number of workers
Reduce wages
questions.explanation: When $MRP > W$, the additional worker brings in more revenue than they cost, so hiring more workers increases profit.

questions.question: The law of diminishing marginal returns states that:
options: As more labor is hired, total output always decreases
As more labor is hired, marginal product eventually decreases
Workers become less productive over time
Technology improvements always offset labor productivity
questions.explanation: Holding other inputs constant, adding more workers eventually leads to smaller increases in output (diminishing marginal product).

questions.question: For a perfectly competitive firm in both product and labor markets, the labor demand curve is:
options: The same as the marginal revenue product curve
The average product curve
Perfectly elastic at the market wage
The total product curve
questions.explanation: Since $P = MR$ in perfect competition, $MRP_L = MP_L \times P$, and the firm hires where $W = MRP_L$, making MRP the labor demand curve.

questions.question: An increase in the price of the firm's output will:
options: Shift the labor demand curve leftward
Shift the labor demand curve rightward
Cause movement along the labor demand curve
Have no effect on labor demand
questions.explanation: Higher output price increases MRP at each employment level, shifting the labor demand curve rightward and increasing the quantity of labor demanded.

questions.question: Technological improvements that increase labor productivity will:
options: Decrease demand for labor
Increase demand for labor
Have no effect on labor demand
Only affect capital demand
questions.explanation: Higher productivity increases marginal product, which increases MRP and thus labor demand at each wage rate.

questions.question: The market demand for labor is derived by:
options: Summing individual firms' labor demand curves horizontally
Averaging all firms' wage rates
Multiplying marginal product by population
Following government labor policies
questions.explanation: The market labor demand curve is the horizontal summation of all individual firms' labor demand (MRP) curves at each wage rate.

questions.question: For a monopoly in the product market, the MRP curve:
options: Lies above the value of marginal product curve
Lies below the value of marginal product curve
Is the same as the value of marginal product curve
Is perfectly elastic
questions.explanation: For a monopoly, $MR < P$, so $MRP_L = MP_L \times MR < MP_L \times P = VMP_L$, where VMP is the value of marginal product.

questions.question: If a firm is a price maker in the product market but a price taker in the labor market, it will hire where:
options: $W = MP_L \times P$
$W = MP_L \times MR$
$W = AP_L \times P$
$W = TP_L \div L$
questions.explanation: Since $MR < P$ for price makers, the firm hires where wage equals $MP_L \times MR$ (MRP), not $MP_L \times P$ (VMP).

questions.question: An increase in the wage rate causes:
options: A rightward shift in labor demand
A leftward shift in labor demand
Movement along the labor demand curve
No change in labor employment
questions.explanation: A wage change causes movement along the labor demand curve, while factors like technology or output price cause shifts of the curve.

questions.question: The elasticity of labor demand measures:
options: How responsive quantity demanded is to wage changes
How fast wages increase over time
The slope of the production function
Worker satisfaction with wages
questions.explanation: Labor demand elasticity = % change in quantity demanded ÷ % change in wage. It indicates how sensitive employment is to wage changes.

questions.question: Labor demand is generally more elastic when:
options: Labor costs are a small share of total costs
It is difficult to substitute other inputs for labor
The demand for the final product is elastic
Workers have specialized skills
questions.explanation: When product demand is elastic, small price increases cause large output decreases, making labor demand more responsive to wage changes.

questions.question: According to Hicks-Marshall laws, labor demand is more elastic when:
options: The elasticity of substitution between inputs is low
The supply of other inputs is inelastic
The elasticity of product demand is high
Labor is essential to production
questions.explanation: The Hicks-Marshall laws state labor demand elasticity is higher when: (1) product demand is elastic, (2) substitution with other inputs is easy, (3) supply of other inputs is elastic, and (4) labor's share of costs is large.

questions.question: If the price of capital decreases and capital and labor are substitutes, the demand for labor will:
options: Increase due to the output effect
Decrease due to the substitution effect
Definitely increase overall
Definitely decrease overall
questions.explanation: The substitution effect (firms substitute toward cheaper capital) reduces labor demand, while the output effect (lower costs increase output) may increase it. The net effect is ambiguous.

questions.question: The value of marginal product (VMP) differs from marginal revenue product (MRP) when:
options: The firm is a price taker in the labor market
The firm is a price taker in the product market
The firm has market power in the product market
Workers are unionized
questions.explanation: $VMP = MP_L \times P$ while $MRP = MP_L \times MR$. They differ when the firm faces a downward-sloping demand curve ($MR < P$).

questions.question: A firm's short-run labor demand curve is downward sloping because of:
options: Diminishing marginal product of labor
Increasing returns to scale
Rising wage rates
Worker preferences
questions.explanation: As more labor is hired with fixed capital, MP declines, causing MRP to decline and creating a downward-sloping labor demand curve.

questions.question: In the long run, when all inputs are variable, the labor demand curve:
options: Becomes perfectly elastic
Becomes perfectly inelastic
Is generally more elastic than in the short run
Is generally less elastic than in the short run
questions.explanation: Long-run labor demand is more elastic because firms can adjust all inputs, making substitution between labor and capital easier.

questions.question: The fundamental principle underlying labor demand is that firms hire workers:
options: Until total product is maximized
As long as the additional revenue exceeds additional cost
Based solely on worker qualifications
According to government quotas
questions.explanation: Firms are profit-maximizers who hire additional workers as long as MRP ≥ wage, following the marginal decision rule.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand derived demand, MRP, and the factors affecting labor demand.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basics but should review the MRP concept, profit-maximizing hiring rule, and factors shifting labor demand.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: the derived demand concept, MRP calculation, and how firms determine how many workers to hire.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember that labor demand comes from product demand, and firms hire workers until MRP = wage.
